ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
This course definitely improved my academic writing in many ways. I feel much more confident in my ability to effectively construct essays and substantiate the claims and arguments that I make in them. I also feel like my word choice has strengthened a lot after taking this course. Overall, I feel like a much better writer than I was before, and I am more confident that I will be successful in future writing assignments.

Not to mention, I have a much greater understanding of tourism, its impact, and the true motivations behind it.
I learned how to compare academic texts, how to write an academic essay, and how to revise a paper.
useful writing skills (structure, topic sentences, voices and tones etc) and how to analyze readings and extract own claims

This course helped me to hone in my writing skills especially showing my evidence to the reader. Also, the course helped me adapt to the ways college professors will grade my essays, compared to a high school English course.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths - The writing instruction in this course is great. After each essay, and throughout the writing process of each essay, Professor Newton gives a great blend of positive feedback and constructive criticism. The essays cover a variety of writing styles (close reading, research, personal experiences, etc.). Additionally, The topic itself is very interesting, and I found my outlook on tourism. entirely changed after having taken this course.

Weaknesses - My only complaint is that the first essay was hard to grasp conceptually, but I don't think this issue applied to everyone. I'm having a hard time trying to think of any weaknesses.
The readings in this course were interesting and my writing skills improved. I can't think of weaknesses of the course.

strength: the course is very engaging and teaches many useful writing skills, and the readings are really fun!
weakness: feel like the second half of semester has a lot of writing-focused classes but less new reading materials, but may be better if adjust the balance a little bit and still have interesting readings as the first half

Having one less essay would be nice to give me some breathing room. I enjoyed the discussions in class about tourism and how they evolved with each reading they did. I would like a day or two of more show and tell or for the professor to have us talk about our own stories of tourism and not other people's.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. Professor Newton gives great feedback and constructive criticism on essays. As you progress through the course, the writing process becomes more and more independent, and the central research essay is a great chance write about something that truly interests you. The personal essay at the end is also a nice break from academic writing. Additionally, The topic itself is very interesting. Overall I enjoyed this class and I think it has improved my skills as a writer (and as a reader) drastically.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student because the readings are interesting and it will help improve their writing skills.

Recommend!! The readings are really interesting and thought-provoking if you love/care about traveling. I have a more nuanced understanding of travel after the readings. Also, Pam is amazing, she gives pretty helpful feedback every time and it contributes a lot to further writing!

Yes I would. If I knew a student who wanted a good intro to college writing course and they were into tourism, this course would be perfect because it includes both the amazing points of touring a new p[lace, but also the consequences of travel and how communities reel from the impacts.
